title: Matrix.copy
content: Matrix.copy copy Creates and returns a new Matrix{T} with the same dimensions as this matrix and a copy of the underlying data.

title: Matrix.splitCols
content:
Matrix.splitCols 
splitCols 
Splits a matrix along column direction according to given indices. Returns (matrix including cols according to indices, rest)

title: Matrix.permuteRowsBy
content: Matrix.permuteRowsBy permuteRowsBy Creates a new matrix by permuting the rows of matrix m according to the permutation P. That is, row i of the result is row P(i) of m.

title: Matrix.ofRowSeq
content:
Matrix.ofRowSeq 
ofRowSeq 
 Creates a matrix from a sequence of row sequences

title: Matrix.mapi
content: Matrix.mapi mapi Applies a function f to each element of the matrix, returning a new matrix with updated values. The iteration occurs in row-major order for performance.

title: Matrix.foldi
content: Matrix.foldi foldi Folds over each element in row-major order, accumulating a result of type 'State. The callback f receives (currentState, rowIndex, colIndex, elementValue), and returns the new state.

title: Matrix.sum
content:
Matrix.sum 
sum 
 Sums all elements in the matrix.

title: Permutation
content: Permutation The Permutation module defines a type and helper functions for representing and constructing permutations from integer arrays. Permutation.ofFreshArray ofFreshArray Permutation.ofArray ofArray Permutation.sign sign Permutation.ofPairs ofPairs Permutation.swap swap Permutation.reversal reversal Permutation.rotation rotation Permutation.identity identity Permutation.inverse inverse

title: Permutation.ofFreshArray
content:
Permutation.ofFreshArray ofFreshArray Validates that the given integer array arr is a valid permutation of length n (i.e., it contains every integer from 0 to n-1 exactly once), then returns a function P(i) = arr[i].
Throws an exception if arr is invalid.

title: Permutation.ofArray
content: Permutation.ofArray ofArray Makes a copy of arr, then calls ofFreshArray. Useful for preserving the original array.

title: Permutation.sign
content:
Permutation.sign 
sign 
 Computes the sign (+1.0 or -1.0) of a permutation P, 
 given its domain size n. sign(P) = (-1)^(n - numCycles).

title: Vector.splitVector
content:
Vector.splitVector 
splitVector 

 Splits the vector `v` into two parts based on `indices`.
 The elements at positions in `indices` end up in `nvi`,
 all others go into `nv`.

title: Vector.permuteBy
content: Vector.permuteBy permuteBy Creates a new vector that is the result of applying the permutation P to the vector b. The element result.[i] becomes b.[P(i)].

title: Matrix<'T>.GetSlice
content:
Matrix<'T>.GetSlice 
GetSlice 
 Convenience "slice indexer" for F# syntax: mat.[r1..r2, c1..c2].
 Internally calls GetSlice(...).

title: Matrix<'T>.GetSlice
content:
Matrix<'T>.GetSlice 
GetSlice 

 Returns a new Matrix<'T> that is the slice of rows [rowStart..rowEnd] 
 and columns [colStart..colEnd]. If any of these bounds is omitted, 
 it defaults to the full range in that dimension.

title: Matrix<'T>.SetCol
content:
Matrix<'T>.SetCol 
SetCol 
 Sets column <paramref name="j"/> of this matrix to the contents of <paramref name="colData"/>.

title: Matrix<'T>.SetRow
content:
Matrix<'T>.SetRow 
SetRow 
 Sets row <paramref name="i"/> of this matrix to the contents of <paramref name="rowData"/>.
 The length of <paramref name="rowData"/> must match the number of columns in this matrix.

title: Matrix<'T>.matmul
content:
Matrix<'T>.matmul 
matmul 
 Standard matrix multiplication (A x B).
 A is (M x K), B is (K x N) => result is (M x N).
 Then each (row of A) .dot. (row of B^T) is done with Vector<'T> chunks.

content:
Matrix<'T>.multiply 
multiply 
 Element-wise multiplication Hadamard product)

title: Matrix<'T>.multiplyRowVector
content:
Matrix<'T>.multiplyRowVector 
multiplyRowVector 
 Computes row-vector v (length = mat.NumRows) times matrix mat (size = [NumRows × NumCols]),
 returning a new vector of length mat.NumCols. Uses chunk-based SIMD with manual gather.

title: Permutation
content: Permutation A permutation represented as a function from indices to indices. If P is a Permutation, then P(i) gives the new row index for row i (or vice versa).

title: SIMDUtils
content:
SIMDUtils 
 A utility class for performing SIMD (Single Instruction, Multiple Data) operations on arrays. 
SIMDUtils.``.ctor`` 
``.ctor`` 
SIMDUtils.fold 
fold 
SIMDUtils.map 
map 
SIMDUtils.map2RangeInPlace 
map2RangeInPlace 
SIMDUtils.map2Unchecked 
map2Unchecked 
SIMDUtils.mapFoldUnchecked 
mapFoldUnchecked 
SIMDUtils.mapRangeInPlace 
mapRangeInPlace 
SIMDUtils.mapScalar 
mapScalar

title: SIMDUtils.fold
content:
SIMDUtils.fold 
fold 

 Reduces an array to a single value using a binary operation, with SIMD optimization.

title: SIMDUtils.map
content:
SIMDUtils.map 
map 

 Applies a safe element-wise unary operation on an array using SIMD for performance.

title: SIMDUtils.map2RangeInPlace
content:
SIMDUtils.map2RangeInPlace 
map2RangeInPlace 
 In-place combination of two arrays (dst, src) over 'count' elements,
 starting from 'dstStartIndex' and 'srcStartIndex' respectively.
 Uses 'fv' for chunked SIMD processing and 'f' for leftover scalar elements.

title: SIMDUtils.map2Unchecked
content:
SIMDUtils.map2Unchecked 
map2Unchecked 

 Applies an element-wise binary operation on two arrays using SIMD for performance.

title: SIMDUtils.mapRangeInPlace
content:
SIMDUtils.mapRangeInPlace 
mapRangeInPlace 
 In-place transformation of v[startIndex..(startIndex + count - 1)]
 using a SIMD operation (fv) for chunked parts and a scalar function (f) for leftovers.

title: SIMDUtils.mapScalar
content:
SIMDUtils.mapScalar 
mapScalar 

 Applies an element-wise binary operation between an array and a scalar using SIMD for performance.

title: Vector.add
content:
Vector.add 
add 
 Adds two vectors element-wise.
 <param name="v1">The first vector.</param>
 <param name="v2">The second vector.</param>
 <returns>A new vector containing the element-wise sum of the two input vectors.</returns>
 <exception cref="System.ArgumentException">Thrown when the vectors have different lengths.</exception>

title: Vector.addScalar
content:
Vector.addScalar 
addScalar 
 Adds a scalar to each element of the vector.
 <param name="v">The vector.</param>
 <param name="scalar">The scalar value to add.</param>
 <returns>A new vector with the scalar added to each element.</returns>

title: Vector.divide
content:
Vector.divide 
divide 
 Divides the first vector by the second vector element-wise.
 <param name="v1">The first vector.</param>
 <param name="v2">The second vector.</param>
 <returns>A new vector containing the element-wise division of the two input vectors.</returns>
 <exception cref="System.ArgumentException">Thrown when the vectors have different lengths.</exception>

content:
Vector.divideScalar 
divideScalar

 <returns>A new vector with each element divided by the scalar.</returns>

content:
Vector.dot 
dot

 <param name="v1">The first vector.</param>

 <exception cref="System.ArgumentException">Thrown when the vectors have different lengths.</exception>

pseudoInvers

qrDecompose

qrModifiedGramSchmidt 
LinearAlgebra.solveLinearQR

title: LinearAlgebra.backSubstitute
content:
LinearAlgebra.backSubstitute 
backSubstitute 
Back substitute to solve R * x = y 
R is upper triangular

title: LinearAlgebra.cholesky
content: LinearAlgebra.cholesky cholesky Computes the Cholesky factor L of a symmetric positive-definite matrix A, returning L as a lower-triangular Matrix{T} such that A = L * L^T. Throws if A is not positive-definite (i.e., if any diagonal element ≤ 0).

title: LinearAlgebra.determinant
content:
LinearAlgebra.determinant 
determinant 
 Computes the determinant of a square matrix A by factoring A = P * L * U,
 then det(A) = sign(P) * ∏ diag(U). 
 (Assumes L has diag=1, as in Doolittle.)

title: LinearAlgebra.hatMatrix
content:
LinearAlgebra.hatMatrix 
hatMatrix 
computes the hat matrix by the QR decomposition of the designmatrix used in ordinary least squares approaches

title: LinearAlgebra.inverse
content:
LinearAlgebra.inverse 
inverse 

 Computes the inverse of a square matrix A using its LU factorization.
 If A is n×n, we factor A = P * L * U, then solve A * X = I for X, returning X = A^-1.

title: LinearAlgebra.leastSquares
content:
LinearAlgebra.leastSquares leastSquares Given A[m,n] and B[m] solves AX = B for X[n].
When m => n, have over constrained system, finds least squares solution for X.
When m < n, have under constrained system, finds least norm solution for X.

title: LinearAlgebra.leastSquaresCholesky
content:
LinearAlgebra.leastSquaresCholesky leastSquaresCholesky Given A[m,n] and b[m] solves AX = b for X[n].
When the system is under constrained,
for example when the columns of A are not linearly independent,
then it will not give sensible results.

title: LinearAlgebra.leverage
content:
LinearAlgebra.leverage leverage computes the leverage directly by QR decomposition of the designmatrix used in ordinary least squares approaches
and computing of the diagnonal entries of the Hat matrix, known as the leverages of the regressors

title: LinearAlgebra.leverageBy
content:
LinearAlgebra.leverageBy 
leverageBy 
computes the leverages of every dataPoint of a dataSet given by the diagonal of the hat matrix.

title: LinearAlgebra.luDecompose
content:
LinearAlgebra.luDecompose 
luDecompose 
 Computes the LU factorization of a square matrix A with partial pivoting.
 That is, P * A = L * U, where P is a permutation, and L, U are lower/upper triangular.
 Returns (Permutation P, L, U).

title: LinearAlgebra.pseudoInvers
content:
LinearAlgebra.pseudoInvers 
pseudoInvers 

 Computes the Moore-Penrose pseudoinverse of a matrix using a QR-based approach. 
 If the matrix is overdetermined (m > n), returns (R⁻¹ Qᵀ) for A = Q R with A[m×n]. 
 If underdetermined (m < n), uses the transpose trick, then returns the transpose of the partial solution.

title: LinearAlgebra.qrDecompose
content:
LinearAlgebra.qrDecompose 
qrDecompose 
 QR decomposition using Householder reflections

title: LinearAlgebra.qrModifiedGramSchmidt
content:
LinearAlgebra.qrModifiedGramSchmidt 
qrModifiedGramSchmidt 
QR decomposition using modified Gram-Schmidt 
Returns Q and R such that A = QR

title: LinearAlgebra.solveLinearQR
content:
LinearAlgebra.solveLinearQR 
solveLinearQR 
 Solve A * x = b for x, where A is a square matrix (n×n) and b is a vector (length n).

title: LinearAlgebra.solveLinearSystem
content:
LinearAlgebra.solveLinearSystem 
solveLinearSystem 
 Solves the system A * x = b for x, using LU factorization with partial pivoting.
 A must be square, and b must have length = A.NumRows.

title: LinearAlgebra.solveLinearSystems
content:
LinearAlgebra.solveLinearSystems 
solveLinearSystems 
 Solves the system of linear equations A * X = B using LU factorization.
 A must be square; B must have the same number of rows as A. 
 Returns a matrix X s.t. A*X = B.

title: LinearAlgebra.solveTriangularLinearSystem
content:
LinearAlgebra.solveTriangularLinearSystem 
solveTriangularLinearSystem 
 Solve K * x = v (triangular system) in-place, returning a copy of x.
 K must be n×n, v must be length n. 
 isLower = true => forward substitution
 isLower = false => backward substitution

title: LinearAlgebra.solveTriangularLinearSystems
content:
LinearAlgebra.solveTriangularLinearSystems 
solveTriangularLinearSystems 
 Solve K * X = B for X, where K is a triangular matrix (lower or upper).
 K is square of size n×n; B is n×m. Returns an n×m result X.

title: LinearAlgebra.subScaledRowInPlace
content:
LinearAlgebra.subScaledRowInPlace 
subScaledRowInPlace 
 Subtract `scaleVal * src[srcOffset..srcOffset+count-1]` from
 `dst[dstOffset..dstOffset+count-1]` in place.

title: Gamma
content:
Gamma 
 Approximations for the gamma function and related functions.

 The gamma function (represented by Γ, the capital letter gamma from the Greek alphabet) is one commonly used extension 
 of the factorial function to complex numbers:

 Γ(x) = (x-1)!

The gamma function is defined for all complex numbers except the non-positive integers.
Gamma._gamma _gamma Gamma._gammaLn _gammaLn Gamma.digamma digamma Gamma.digammaPositive digammaPositive Gamma.gamma gamma Gamma.gammaLn gammaLn Gamma.gammpapprox gammpapprox Gamma.gcf gcf Gamma.gser gser Gamma.lowerIncomplete lowerIncomplete Gamma.lowerIncompleteRegularized lowerIncompleteRegularized Gamma.upperIncomplete upperIncomplete Gamma.upperIncompleteRegularized upperIncompleteRegularized Gamma.maximum maximum

title: Gamma._gamma
content:
Gamma._gamma 
_gamma 

 Computes an approximation of the real value of the gamma function using the Lanczos Coefficients described in Numerical Recipes (Press et al) 
 
 
 The caller is responsible to handle edge cases such as nan, infinity, and -infinity in the input

title: Gamma._gammaLn
content:
Gamma._gammaLn 
_gammaLn 

 Computes an approximation of the real value of the log gamma function using the Lanczos Coefficients described in Numerical Recipes (Press et al)
 

 The caller is responsible to handle edge cases such as nan, infinity, and -infinity in the input

title: Gamma.digamma
content:
Gamma.digamma 
digamma 
 Full digamma function ψ(x),

title: Gamma.digammaPositive
content:
Gamma.digammaPositive 
digammaPositive 

 Optimized digamma function for x > 1. Skips reflection and tan-based correction.
 Use when x is guaranteed to be greater than 1.

title: Gamma.gamma
content:
Gamma.gamma 
gamma 

 Computes an approximation of the real value of the gamma function using the Lanczos Coefficients described in Numerical Recipes (Press et al) 
 

 Edge cases in the input (nan, infinity, and -infinity) are catched and handled. 
 This might be slower than the unchecked version `_gamma` but does not require input sanitation to get expected results for these cases.

title: Gamma.gammaLn
content:
Gamma.gammaLn 
gammaLn 

 Computes an approximation of the real value of the log gamma function using the Lanczos Coefficients described in Numerical Recipes (Press et al)
 

 Edge cases in the input (nan, infinity, and -infinity) are catched and handled. 
 This might be slower than the unchecked version `_gamma` but does not require input sanitation to get expected results for these cases.

title: Gamma.gammpapprox
content:
Gamma.gammpapprox 
gammpapprox 

 Gauss-Legendre quadrature approximation for the regularized gamma function

title: Gamma.gcf
content:
Gamma.gcf 
gcf 

 Continued fraction representation of the upper incomplete gamma function Q(a,x)

title: Gamma.gser
content:
Gamma.gser 
gser 

 Series representation of the lower incomplete gamma function P(a,x)

title: Gamma.lowerIncomplete
content:
Gamma.lowerIncomplete 
lowerIncomplete 

 Unregularized lower incomplete gamma function γ(a, x)

title: Gamma.lowerIncompleteRegularized
content:
Gamma.lowerIncompleteRegularized 
lowerIncompleteRegularized 

 Regularized lower incomplete gamma function P(a,x)

title: Gamma.upperIncomplete
content:
Gamma.upperIncomplete 
upperIncomplete 

 Computes the unregularized upper incomplete gamma function Γ̄(a, x) = Γ(a) · Q(a, x),
 where Q(a, x) is the regularized upper incomplete gamma function.

title: Gamma.upperIncompleteRegularized
content:
Gamma.upperIncompleteRegularized 
upperIncompleteRegularized 

 Regularized upper incomplete gamma function Q(a,x)

title: Coverage Analysis Setup
content:
Coverage Analysis Setup
This document describes the code coverage analysis and reporting setup for FsMath.
Overview
The project uses Coverlet for code coverage collection and reporting. Coverage reports are generated automatically during CI/CD builds with detailed HTML reports available as artifacts and coverage summaries in pull requests.
Tools Used

Coverlet: .NET code coverage library
ReportGenerator: Tool for generating HTML/XML coverage reports
GitHub Actions: CI/CD automation with coverage integration

Local Development
Running Tests with Coverage
# Basic coverage collection
./build.sh runtestswithcoverage   # Linux/macOS
./build.cmd runtestswithcoverage  # Windows

# Full coverage report generation
./scripts/generate-coverage.sh   # Linux/macOS
./scripts/generate-coverage.ps1  # Windows

Coverage Configuration
The coverage setup is configured through several files:

coverlet.runsettings: MSBuild test settings for coverage collection
.coverletrc: Coverlet-specific configuration for exclusions
Test project files include coverlet.msbuild and coverlet.collector packages

Exclusions
The following items are excluded from coverage analysis:
- Test assemblies and test-related code
- Generated code (marked with attributes)
- Program entry points
- Obsolete code
CI/CD Integration
GitHub Actions Workflow
The build-and-test.yml workflow includes:

Test Execution: Runs tests with coverage collection using XPlat Code Coverage
Report Generation: Creates HTML and Cobertura reports using ReportGenerator
PR Comments: Adds coverage summary comments to pull requests
Artifact Storage: Stores HTML coverage reports as build artifacts

Coverage Thresholds

Warning threshold: 60% coverage
Good threshold: 80% coverage
CI doesn't fail on coverage below thresholds (informational only)

Coverage Reports
Local Reports

Location: TestResults/CoverageReport/
Format: HTML (main), Cobertura XML, JSON summary
View: Open TestResults/CoverageReport/index.html in browser

GitHub Integration

Coverage Badge: Generated in pull request comments
PR Integration: Coverage changes shown in pull request comments
Artifact Downloads: Full HTML reports available from GitHub Actions

Troubleshooting
Common Issues

No coverage data: Ensure tests are running and coverlet.collector is installed
Low coverage: Check exclusions in .coverletrc and coverlet.runsettings
Report generation fails: Verify ReportGenerator is installed globally

Debug Coverage Collection
# Run with verbose logging
dotnet test --collect:"XPlat Code Coverage" --logger "console;verbosity=detailed"

# Check for coverage files
find TestResults -name "*.cobertura.xml"

Maintenance
The coverage setup should be reviewed periodically to:

Update exclusion patterns as the codebase evolves
Adjust coverage thresholds based on project maturity
Update tool versions (Coverlet, ReportGenerator)
Review GitHub Actions workflow and coverage reporting
